memoryMiB.description:
The amount (in MiB) of memory used by the task.

If using the EC2 launch type, this field is optional and any value can be used.
If using the Fargate launch type, this field is required and you must use one of the following values,
which determines your range of valid values for the cpu parameter:

512 (0.5 GB), 1024 (1 GB), 2048 (2 GB) - Available cpu values: 256 (.25 vCPU)

1024 (1 GB), 2048 (2 GB), 3072 (3 GB), 4096 (4 GB) - Available cpu values: 512 (.5 vCPU)

2048 (2 GB), 3072 (3 GB), 4096 (4 GB), 5120 (5 GB), 6144 (6 GB), 7168 (7 GB), 8192 (8 GB) - Available cpu values: 1024 (1 vCPU)

Between 4096 (4 GB) and 16384 (16 GB) in increments of 1024 (1 GB) - Available cpu values: 2048 (2 vCPU)

Between 8192 (8 GB) and 30720 (30 GB) in increments of 1024 (1 GB) - Available cpu values: 4096 (4 vCPU)

networkMode.description:
The networking mode to use for the containers in the task.

On Fargate, the only supported networking mode is AwsVpc.

pidMode.description:
The process namespace to use for the containers in the task.

Not supported in Fargate and Windows containers.

placementConstraints.description:
The placement constraints to use for tasks in the service.

You can specify a maximum of 10 constraints per task (this limit includes
constraints in the task definition and those specified at run time).

Not supported in Fargate.

maxEventAge.description:
The maximum age of a request that Lambda sends to a function for processing.

Minimum: 60 seconds
Maximum: 6 hours

retryAttempts.description:
The maximum number of times to retry when the function returns an error.

Minimum: 0
Maximum: 2

allowAllOutbound.description:
Whether to allow the Lambda to send all network traffic.

If set to false, you must individually add traffic rules to allow the
Lambda to connect to network targets.

allowPublicSubnet.description:
Lambda Functions in a public subnet can NOT access the internet.

Use this property to acknowledge this limitation and still place the function in a public subnet.

architecture.description: The system architectures compatible with this lambda function.

codeSigningConfig.description: Code signing config associated with this function.

currentVersionOptions.description: Options for the `lambda.Version` resource automatically created by the `fn.currentVersion` method.

deadLetterQueue.description: The SQS queue to use if DLQ is enabled.

deadLetterQueueEnabled.description:
Enabled DLQ.

If `deadLetterQueue` is undefined,
an SQS queue with default options will be defined for your Function.

description.description: A description of the function.

environment.description:
Key-value pairs that Lambda caches and makes available for your Lambda functions.

Use environment variables to apply configuration changes, such
as test and production environment configurations, without changing your
Lambda function source code.

environmentEncryption.description: The AWS KMS key that's used to encrypt your function's environment variables.

events.description:
Event sources for this function.

You can also add event sources using `addEventSource`.

filesystem.description: The filesystem configuration for the lambda function.

initialPolicy.description:
Initial policy statements to add to the created Lambda Role.

You can call `addToRolePolicy` to the created lambda to add statements post creation.

insightsVersion.description: Specify the version of CloudWatch Lambda insights to use for monitoring.

layers.description:
A list of layers to add to the function's execution environment.

You can configure your Lambda function to pull in
additional code during initialization in the form of layers. Layers are packages of libraries or other dependencies
that can be used by multiple functions.

logRetention.description:
The number of days log events are kept in CloudWatch Logs.

When updating
this property, unsetting it doesn't remove the log retention policy. To
remove the retention policy, set the value to `INFINITE`.

logRetentionRetryOptions.description:
When log retention is specified, a custom resource attempts to create the CloudWatch log group.

These options control the retry policy when interacting with CloudWatch APIs.

logRetentionRole.description: The IAM role for the Lambda function associated with the custom resource that sets the retention policy.

memorySize.description:
The amount of memory, in MB, that is allocated to your Lambda function.

Lambda uses this value to proportionally allocate the amount of CPU
power. For more information, see Resource Model in the AWS Lambda
Developer Guide.

reservedConcurrentExecutions.description: The maximum of concurrent executions you want to reserve for the function.

role.description:
Lambda execution role.

This is the role that will be assumed by the function upon execution.
It controls the permissions that the function will have. The Role must
be assumable by the 'lambda.amazonaws.com' service principal.

The default Role automatically has permissions granted for Lambda execution. If you
provide a Role, you must add the relevant AWS managed policies yourself.

The relevant managed policies are "service-role/AWSLambdaBasicExecutionRole" and
"service-role/AWSLambdaVPCAccessExecutionRole".

securityGroup.description:
What security group to associate with the Lambda's network interfaces. This property is being deprecated, consider using securityGroups instead.

Only used if 'vpc' is supplied.

Use securityGroups property instead.
Function constructor will throw an error if both are specified.

securityGroups.description:
The list of security groups to associate with the Lambda's network interfaces.

Only used if 'vpc' is supplied.

timeout.description:
The function execution time (in seconds) after which Lambda terminates the function.

Because the execution time affects cost, set this value
based on the function's expected execution time.

tracing.description: Enable AWS X-Ray Tracing for Lambda Function.

vpc.description:
VPC network to place Lambda network interfaces.

Specify this if the Lambda function needs to access resources in a VPC.

vpcSubnets.description:
Where to place the network interfaces within the VPC.

Only used if 'vpc' is supplied. Note: internet access for Lambdas
requires a NAT gateway, so picking Public subnets is not allowed.

code.description:
The source code of your Lambda function.

You can point to a file in an
Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) bucket or specify your source
code as inline text.

handler.description:
The name of the method within your code that Lambda calls to execute your function.

The format includes the file name. It can also include
namespaces and other qualifiers, depending on the runtime.
For more information, see https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/gettingstarted-features.html#gettingstarted-features-programmingmodel.

Use `Handler.FROM_IMAGE` when defining a function from a Docker image.

NOTE: If you specify your source code as inline text by specifying the
ZipFile property within the Code property, specify index.function_name as
the handler.

runtime.description:
The runtime environment for the Lambda function that you are uploading.

For valid values, see the Runtime property in the AWS Lambda Developer
Guide.

Use `Runtime.FROM_IMAGE` when when defining a function from a Docker image.

stackId.description: The stack ID of Lambda@Edge function.

cachePolicyName.description:
A unique name to identify the cache policy.

The name must only include '-', '_', or alphanumeric characters.

comment.description: A comment to describe the cache policy.

cookieBehavior.description: Determines whether any cookies in viewer requests are included in the cache key and automatically included in requests that CloudFront sends to the origin.

defaultTtl.description:
The default amount of time for objects to stay in the CloudFront cache.

Only used when the origin does not send Cache-Control or Expires headers with the object.

enableAcceptEncodingBrotli.description: Whether to normalize and include the `Accept-Encoding` header in the cache key when the `Accept-Encoding` header is 'br'.

enableAcceptEncodingGzip.description: Whether to normalize and include the `Accept-Encoding` header in the cache key when the `Accept-Encoding` header is 'gzip'.

headerBehavior.description: Determines whether any HTTP headers are included in the cache key and automatically included in requests that CloudFront sends to the origin.

maxTtl.description:
The maximum amount of time for objects to stay in the CloudFront cache.

CloudFront uses this value only when the origin sends Cache-Control or Expires headers with the object.

minTtl.description: The minimum amount of time for objects to stay in the CloudFront cache.

queryStringBehavior.description: Determines whether any query strings are included in the cache key and automatically included in requests that CloudFront sends to the origin.

eventType.description: The type of event which should invoke the function.

function.description: The CloudFront function that will be invoked.

eventType.description: The lambda event type defines at which event the lambda is called during the request lifecycle.

lambdaFunction.description: A version of the lambda to associate.

includeBody.description:
Allows a Lambda function to have read access to the body content.

Only valid for "request" event types (`ORIGIN_REQUEST` or `VIEWER_REQUEST`).
See https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudFront/latest/DeveloperGuide/lambda-include-body-access.html

allowedMethods.description: The method this CloudFront distribution responds do.

cachedMethods.description: Which methods are cached by CloudFront by default.

compress.description: If CloudFront should automatically compress some content types.

defaultTtl.description:
The default amount of time CloudFront will cache an object.

This value applies only when your custom origin does not add HTTP headers,
such as Cache-Control max-age, Cache-Control s-maxage, and Expires to objects.

forwardedValues.description: The values CloudFront will forward to the origin when making a request.

functionAssociations.description: The CloudFront functions to invoke before serving the contents.

isDefaultBehavior.description:
If this behavior is the default behavior for the distribution.

You must specify exactly one default distribution per CloudFront distribution.
The default behavior is allowed to omit the "path" property.

lambdaFunctionAssociations.description: Declares associated lambda@edge functions for this distribution behaviour.

maxTtl.description: The max amount of time you want objects to stay in the cache before CloudFront queries your origin.

minTtl.description: The minimum amount of time that you want objects to stay in the cache before CloudFront queries your origin.

pathPattern.description:
The path this behavior responds to.

Required for all non-default behaviors. (The default behavior implicitly has "*" as the path pattern. )

trustedKeyGroups.description: A list of Key Groups that CloudFront can use to validate signed URLs or signed cookies.

trustedSigners.description:
Trusted signers is how CloudFront allows you to serve private content.

The signers are the account IDs that are allowed to sign cookies/presigned URLs for this distribution.

If you pass a non empty value, all requests for this behavior must be signed (no public access will be allowed)

viewerProtocolPolicy.description: The viewer policy for this behavior.

domainName.description:
The domain name of the custom origin.

Should not include the path - that should be in the parent SourceConfiguration

allowedOriginSSLVersions.description: The SSL versions to use when interacting with the origin.

originHeaders.description: Any additional headers to pass to the origin.

originKeepaliveTimeout.description: The keep alive timeout when making calls in seconds.

originPath.description: The relative path to the origin root to use for sources.

originProtocolPolicy.description: The protocol (http or https) policy to use when interacting with the origin.

originReadTimeout.description: The read timeout when calling the origin in seconds.

originShieldRegion.description: When you enable Origin Shield in the AWS Region that has the lowest latency to your origin, you can get better network performance.

s3BucketSource.description: The source bucket to serve content from.

originAccessIdentity.description: The optional Origin Access Identity of the origin identity cloudfront will use when calling your s3 bucket.

originHeaders.description: Any additional headers to pass to the origin.

originPath.description: The relative path to the origin root to use for sources.

originShieldRegion.description: When you enable Origin Shield in the AWS Region that has the lowest latency to your origin, you can get better network performance.

behaviors.description:
The behaviors associated with this source.

At least one (default) behavior must be included.

connectionAttempts.description:
The number of times that CloudFront attempts to connect to the origin.

You can specify 1, 2, or 3 as the number of attempts.

connectionTimeout.description:
The number of seconds that CloudFront waits when trying to establish a connection to the origin.

You can specify a number of seconds between 1 and 10 (inclusive).

customOriginSource.description: A custom origin source - for all non-s3 sources.

failoverCriteriaStatusCodes.description: HTTP status code to failover to second origin.

failoverCustomOriginSource.description: A custom origin source for failover in case the s3OriginSource returns invalid status code.

failoverS3OriginSource.description: An s3 origin source for failover in case the s3OriginSource returns invalid status code.

originHeaders.description: Any additional headers to pass to the origin.

originPath.description: The relative path to the origin root to use for sources.

originShieldRegion.description: When you enable Origin Shield in the AWS Region that has the lowest latency to your origin, you can get better network performance.

s3OriginSource.description: An s3 origin source - if you're using s3 for your assets.

acmCertRef.description: ARN of an AWS Certificate Manager (ACM) certificate.

names.description:
Domain names on the certificate.

Both main domain name and Subject Alternative Names.

securityPolicy.description:
The minimum version of the SSL protocol that you want CloudFront to use for HTTPS connections.

CloudFront serves your objects only to browsers or devices that support at
least the SSL version that you specify.

sslMethod.description:
How CloudFront should serve HTTPS requests.

See the notes on SSLMethod if you wish to use other SSL termination types.

includeCookies.description: Whether to include the cookies in the logs.

prefix.description: Where in the bucket to store logs.

aliases.description: Domain names on the certificate (both main domain name and Subject Alternative names).

securityPolicy.description:
The minimum version of the SSL protocol that you want CloudFront to use for HTTPS connections.

CloudFront serves your objects only to browsers or devices that support at
least the SSL version that you specify.

sslMethod.description:
How CloudFront should serve HTTPS requests.

See the notes on SSLMethod if you wish to use other SSL termination types.

originConfigs.description:
The origin configurations for this distribution.

Behaviors are a part of the origin.

aliasConfiguration.description: AliasConfiguration is used to configured CloudFront to respond to requests on custom domain names.

comment.description: A comment for this distribution in the CloudFront console.

enabled.description: Enable or disable the distribution.

enableIpV6.description: If your distribution should have IPv6 enabled.

errorConfigurations.description:
How CloudFront should handle requests that are not successful (eg PageNotFound).

By default, CloudFront does not replace HTTP status codes in the 4xx and 5xx range
with custom error messages. CloudFront does not cache HTTP status codes.

geoRestriction.description: Controls the countries in which your content is distributed.

loggingConfig.description:
Optional - if we should enable logging.

You can pass an empty object ({}) to have us auto create a bucket for logging.
Omission of this property indicates no logging is to be enabled.

priceClass.description: The price class for the distribution (this impacts how many locations CloudFront uses for your distribution, and billing).

viewerCertificate.description: Specifies whether you want viewers to use HTTP or HTTPS to request your objects, whether you're using an alternate domain name with HTTPS, and if so, if you're using AWS Certificate Manager (ACM) or a third-party certificate authority.

viewerProtocolPolicy.description: The default viewer policy for incoming clients.

webACLId.description:
Unique identifier that specifies the AWS WAF web ACL to associate with this CloudFront distribution.

To specify a web ACL created using the latest version of AWS WAF, use the ACL ARN, for example
`arn:aws:wafv2:us-east-1:123456789012:global/webacl/ExampleWebACL/473e64fd-f30b-4765-81a0-62ad96dd167a`.

To specify a web ACL created using AWS WAF Classic, use the ACL ID, for example `473e64fd-f30b-4765-81a0-62ad96dd167a`.

cachePolicyId.description: The ID of the cache policy.

eventType.description: The type of event in response to which should the function be invoked.

functionVersion.description:
The version of the Lambda function that will be invoked.

**Note**: it's not possible to use the '$LATEST' function version for Lambda@Edge!

includeBody.description:
Allows a Lambda function to have read access to the body content.

Only valid for "request" event types (`ORIGIN_REQUEST` or `VIEWER_REQUEST`).
See https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudFront/latest/DeveloperGuide/lambda-include-body-access.html

originRequestPolicyId.description: The ID of the origin request policy.

connectionAttempts.description:
The number of times that CloudFront attempts to connect to the origin;

valid values are 1, 2, or 3 attempts.

connectionTimeout.description:
The number of seconds that CloudFront waits when trying to establish a connection to the origin.

Valid values are 1-10 seconds, inclusive.

customHeaders.description: A list of HTTP header names and values that CloudFront adds to requests it sends to the origin.

originPath.description:
An optional path that CloudFront appends to the origin domain name when CloudFront requests content from the origin.

Must begin, but not end, with '/' (e.g., '/production/images').

originShieldRegion.description: When you enable Origin Shield in the AWS Region that has the lowest latency to your origin, you can get better network performance.

httpPort.description: The HTTP port that CloudFront uses to connect to the origin.

httpsPort.description: The HTTPS port that CloudFront uses to connect to the origin.

keepaliveTimeout.description:
Specifies how long, in seconds, CloudFront persists its connection to the origin.

The valid range is from 1 to 60 seconds, inclusive.

originSslProtocols.description: The SSL versions to use when interacting with the origin.

protocolPolicy.description: Specifies the protocol (HTTP or HTTPS) that CloudFront uses to connect to the origin.

readTimeout.description:
Specifies how long, in seconds, CloudFront waits for a response from the origin, also known as the origin response timeout.

The valid range is from 1 to 60 seconds, inclusive.

connectionAttempts.description:
The number of times that CloudFront attempts to connect to the origin;

valid values are 1, 2, or 3 attempts.

connectionTimeout.description:
The number of seconds that CloudFront waits when trying to establish a connection to the origin.

Valid values are 1-10 seconds, inclusive.

An optional path that CloudFront appends to the origin domain name when CloudFront requests content from the origin.

httpsPort.description: The HTTPS port that CloudFront uses to connect to the origin.

keepaliveTimeout.description:
Specifies how long, in seconds, CloudFront persists its connection to the origin.

The valid range is from 1 to 60 seconds, inclusive.

readTimeout.description:
Specifies how long, in seconds, CloudFront waits for a response from the origin, also known as the origin response timeout.

The valid range is from 1 to 60 seconds, inclusive.

The number of times that CloudFront attempts to connect to the origin;

valid values are 1, 2, or 3 attempts.

connectionTimeout.description:
The number of seconds that CloudFront waits when trying to establish a connection to the origin.

Valid values are 1-10 seconds, inclusive.

customHeaders.description: A list of HTTP header names and values that CloudFront adds to requests it sends to the origin.

originPath.description:
An optional path that CloudFront appends to the origin domain name when CloudFront requests content from the origin.

Must begin, but not end, with '/' (e.g., '/production/images').

originShieldRegion.description: When you enable Origin Shield in the AWS Region that has the lowest latency to your origin, you can get better network performance.

originAccessIdentity.description: An optional Origin Access Identity of the origin identity cloudfront will use when calling your s3 bucket.

fallbackOrigin.description: The fallback origin that should serve requests when the primary fails.

primaryOrigin.description: The primary origin that should serve requests for this group.

fallbackStatusCodes.description: The list of HTTP status codes that, when returned from the primary origin, would cause querying the fallback origin.

allowedMethods.description: HTTP methods to allow for this behavior.

cachedMethods.description: HTTP methods to cache for this behavior.

cachePolicy.description:
The cache policy for this behavior.

The cache policy determines what values are included in the cache key,
and the time-to-live (TTL) values for the cache.

compress.description:
Whether you want CloudFront to automatically compress certain files for this cache behavior.

See https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudFront/latest/DeveloperGuide/ServingCompressedFiles.html#compressed-content-cloudfront-file-types
for file types CloudFront will compress.

edgeLambdas.description: The Lambda@Edge functions to invoke before serving the contents.

functionAssociations.description: The CloudFront functions to invoke before serving the contents.

originRequestPolicy.description:
The origin request policy for this behavior.

The origin request policy determines which values (e.g., headers, cookies)
are included in requests that CloudFront sends to the origin.

smoothStreaming.description: Set this to true to indicate you want to distribute media files in the Microsoft Smooth Streaming format using this behavior.

trustedKeyGroups.description: A list of Key Groups that CloudFront can use to validate signed URLs or signed cookies.

viewerProtocolPolicy.description: The protocol that viewers can use to access the files controlled by this behavior.

origin.description: The origin that you want CloudFront to route requests to when they match this behavior.

httpStatus.description: The HTTP status code for which you want to specify a custom error page and/or a caching duration.

responseHttpStatus.description:
The HTTP status code that you want CloudFront to return to the viewer along with the custom error page.

If you specify a value for `responseHttpStatus`, you must also specify a value for `responsePagePath`.

responsePagePath.description: The path to the custom error page that you want CloudFront to return to a viewer when your origin returns the `httpStatus`, for example, /4xx-errors/403-forbidden.html.

ttl.description: The minimum amount of time, in seconds, that you want CloudFront to cache the HTTP status code specified in ErrorCode.

defaultBehavior.description: The default behavior for the distribution.

additionalBehaviors.description: Additional behaviors for the distribution, mapped by the pathPattern that specifies which requests to apply the behavior to.

certificate.description:
A certificate to associate with the distribution.

The certificate must be located in N. Virginia (us-east-1).

comment.description: Any comments you want to include about the distribution.

defaultRootObject.description: The object that you want CloudFront to request from your origin (for example, index.html) when a viewer requests the root URL for your distribution. If no default object is set, the request goes to the origin's root (e.g., example.com/).

domainNames.description:
Alternative domain names for this distribution.

If you want to use your own domain name, such as www.example.com, instead of the cloudfront.net domain name,
you can add an alternate domain name to your distribution. If you attach a certificate to the distribution,
you must add (at least one of) the domain names of the certificate to this list.

enabled.description: Enable or disable the distribution.

enableIpv6.description:
Whether CloudFront will respond to IPv6 DNS requests with an IPv6 address.

If you specify false, CloudFront responds to IPv6 DNS requests with the DNS response code NOERROR and with no IP addresses.
This allows viewers to submit a second request, for an IPv4 address for your distribution.

enableLogging.description: Enable access logging for the distribution.

errorResponses.description: How CloudFront should handle requests that are not successful (e.g., PageNotFound).

geoRestriction.description: Controls the countries in which your content is distributed.

httpVersion.description:
Specify the maximum HTTP version that you want viewers to use to communicate with CloudFront.

For viewers and CloudFront to use HTTP/2, viewers must support TLS 1.2 or later, and must support server name identification (SNI).

logBucket.description: The Amazon S3 bucket to store the access logs in.

logFilePrefix.description: An optional string that you want CloudFront to prefix to the access log filenames for this distribution.

logIncludesCookies.description: Specifies whether you want CloudFront to include cookies in access logs.

minimumProtocolVersion.description:
The minimum version of the SSL protocol that you want CloudFront to use for HTTPS connections.

CloudFront serves your objects only to browsers or devices that support at
least the SSL version that you specify.

priceClass.description:
The price class that corresponds with the maximum price that you want to pay for CloudFront service.

If you specify PriceClass_All, CloudFront responds to requests for your objects from all CloudFront edge locations.
If you specify a price class other than PriceClass_All, CloudFront serves your objects from the CloudFront edge location
that has the lowest latency among the edge locations in your price class.

webAclId.description:
Unique identifier that specifies the AWS WAF web ACL to associate with this CloudFront distribution.

To specify a web ACL created using the latest version of AWS WAF, use the ACL ARN, for example
`arn:aws:wafv2:us-east-1:123456789012:global/webacl/ExampleWebACL/473e64fd-f30b-4765-81a0-62ad96dd167a`.
To specify a web ACL created using AWS WAF Classic, use the ACL ID, for example `473e64fd-f30b-4765-81a0-62ad96dd167a`.

filePath.description: The path of the file to read the code from.

code.description: The source code of the function.

comment.description: A comment to describe the function.

functionName.description: A name to identify the function.

items.description: A list of public keys to add to the key group.

comment.description: A comment to describe the key group.

keyGroupName.description: A name to identify the key group.

comment.description: Any comments you want to include about the origin access identity.
A comment to describe the origin request policy.

cookieBehavior.description: The cookies from viewer requests to include in origin requests.

headerBehavior.description:
The HTTP headers to include in origin requests.

These can include headers from viewer requests and additional headers added by CloudFront.

originRequestPolicyName.description:
A unique name to identify the origin request policy.

The name must only include '-', '_', or alphanumeric characters.

queryStringBehavior.description: The URL query strings from viewer requests to include in origin requests.

encodedKey.description:
The public key that you can use with signed URLs and signed cookies, or with field-level encryption.

The `encodedKey` parameter must include `-----BEGIN PUBLIC KEY-----` and `-----END PUBLIC KEY-----` lines.

comment.description: A comment to describe the public key.

publicKeyName.description: A name to identify the public key.

enabled.description: Indicates whether the accelerator is enabled.

endpointId.description:
Identifier of the endpoint.

Load balancer ARN, instance ID or EIP allocation ID.

preserveClientIp.description:
Forward the client IP address.

GlobalAccelerator will create Network Interfaces in your VPC in order
to preserve the client IP address.

Only applies to Application Load Balancers and EC2 instances.

Client IP address preservation is supported only in specific AWS Regions.
See the GlobalAccelerator Developer Guide for a list.

region.description: The region where this endpoint is located.

weight.description:
Endpoint weight across all endpoints in the group.

Must be a value between 0 and 255.

preserveClientIp.description:
Forward the client IP address in an `X-Forwarded-For` header.

GlobalAccelerator will create Network Interfaces in your VPC in order
to preserve the client IP address.

Client IP address preservation is supported only in specific AWS Regions.
See the GlobalAccelerator Developer Guide for a list.

weight.description:
Endpoint weight across all endpoints in the group.

Must be a value between 0 and 255.

Endpoint weight across all endpoints in the group.

Must be a value between 0 and 255.

preserveClientIp.description:
Forward the client IP address.

GlobalAccelerator will create Network Interfaces in your VPC in order
to preserve the client IP address.

Client IP address preservation is supported only in specific AWS Regions.
See the GlobalAccelerator Developer Guide for a list.

weight.description:
Endpoint weight across all endpoints in the group.

Must be a value between 0 and 255.

Endpoint weight across all endpoints in the group.

Must be a value between 0 and 255.

endpointPort.description:
The endpoint port that you want a listener port to be mapped to.

This is the port on the endpoint, such as the Application Load Balancer or Amazon EC2 instance.

listenerPort.description:
The listener port that you want to map to a specific endpoint port.

This is the port that user traffic arrives to the Global Accelerator on.

endpoints.description: Initial list of endpoints for this group.

healthCheckInterval.description:
The time between health checks for each endpoint.

Must be either 10 or 30 seconds.

healthCheckPath.description: The ping path for health checks (if the protocol is HTTP(S)).

healthCheckPort.description: The port used to perform health checks.

healthCheckProtocol.description: The protocol used to perform health checks.

healthCheckThreshold.description: The number of consecutive health checks required to set the state of a healthy endpoint to unhealthy, or to set an unhealthy endpoint to healthy.

portOverrides.description:
Override the destination ports used to route traffic to an endpoint.

Unless overridden, the port used to hit the endpoint will be the same as the port
that traffic arrives on at the listener.

region.description: The AWS Region where the endpoint group is located.

trafficDialPercentage.description:
The percentage of traffic to send to this AWS Region.

The percentage is applied to the traffic that would otherwise have been
routed to the Region based on optimal routing. Additional traffic is
distributed to other endpoint groups for this listener.

listener.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the listener.

fromPort.description: The first port in the range of ports, inclusive.

toPort.description: The last port in the range of ports, inclusive.

portRanges.description: The list of port ranges for the connections from clients to the accelerator.

clientAffinity.description:
Client affinity to direct all requests from a user to the same endpoint.

If you have stateful applications, client affinity lets you direct all
requests from a user to the same endpoint.

By default, each connection from each client is routed to seperate
endpoints. Set client affinity to SOURCE_IP to route all connections from
a single client to the same endpoint.

protocol.description: The protocol for the connections from clients to the accelerator.

vpc.description: The VPC that AWS Cloud9 will use to communicate with the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (Amazon EC2) instance.

clonedRepositories.description: The AWS CodeCommit repository to be cloned.

description.description: Description of the environment.

instanceType.description: The type of instance to connect to the environment.

subnetSelection.description: The subnetSelection of the VPC that AWS Cloud9 will use to communicate with the Amazon EC2 instance.

cloudWatchLogGroup.description:
Log Group to which CloudTrail to push logs to.

Ignored if sendToCloudWatchLogs is set to false.

cloudWatchLogsRetention.description:
How long to retain logs in CloudWatchLogs.

Ignored if sendToCloudWatchLogs is false or if cloudWatchLogGroup is set.

enableFileValidation.description:
To determine whether a log file was modified, deleted, or unchanged after CloudTrail delivered it, you can use CloudTrail log file integrity validation.

This feature is built using industry standard algorithms: SHA-256 for hashing and SHA-256 with RSA for digital signing.
This makes it computationally infeasible to modify, delete or forge CloudTrail log files without detection.
You can use the AWS CLI to validate the files in the location where CloudTrail delivered them.

encryptionKey.description: The AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) key ID that you want to use to encrypt CloudTrail logs.

includeGlobalServiceEvents.description:
For most services, events are recorded in the region where the action occurred.

For global services such as AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM), AWS STS, Amazon CloudFront, and Route 53,
events are delivered to any trail that includes global services, and are logged as occurring in US East (N. Virginia) Region.

isMultiRegionTrail.description: Whether or not this trail delivers log files from multiple regions to a single S3 bucket for a single account.

kmsKey.description: The AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) key ID that you want to use to encrypt CloudTrail logs.

managementEvents.description:
When an event occurs in your account, CloudTrail evaluates whether the event matches the settings for your trails.

Only events that match your trail settings are delivered to your Amazon S3 bucket and Amazon CloudWatch Logs log group.

This method sets the management configuration for this trail.

Management events provide insight into management operations that are performed on resources in your AWS account.
These are also known as control plane operations.
Management events can also include non-API events that occur in your account.
For example, when a user logs in to your account, CloudTrail logs the ConsoleLogin event.

s3KeyPrefix.description: An Amazon S3 object key prefix that precedes the name of all log files.

sendToCloudWatchLogs.description:
If CloudTrail pushes logs to CloudWatch Logs in addition to S3.

Disabled for cost out of the box.

snsTopic.description: SNS topic that is notified when new log files are published.

trailName.description:
The name of the trail.

We recommend customers do not set an explicit name.

interval.description: The interval, in number of minutes: - For LINEAR, how frequently additional traffic is shifted - For CANARY, how long to shift traffic before the full deployment.

percentage.description: The integer percentage of traffic to shift: - For LINEAR, the percentage to shift every interval - For CANARY, the percentage to shift until the interval passes, before the full deployment.

type.description: The type of deployment config, either CANARY or LINEAR.

deploymentConfigName.description:
The verbatim name of the deployment config.

Must be unique per account/region.
Other parameters cannot be updated if this name is provided.

applicationName.description: The physical, human-readable name of the CodeDeploy Application.
The physical, human-readable name of the CodeDeploy Application.

deploymentInAlarm.description: Whether to automatically roll back a deployment during which one of the configured CloudWatch alarms for this Deployment Group went off.

failedDeployment.description: Whether to automatically roll back a deployment that fails.

stoppedDeployment.description: Whether to automatically roll back a deployment that was manually stopped.

alias.description:
Lambda Alias to shift traffic. Updating the version of the alias will trigger a CodeDeploy deployment.

[disable-awslint:ref-via-interface] since we need to modify the alias CFN resource update policy

alarms.description:
The CloudWatch alarms associated with this Deployment Group.

CodeDeploy will stop (and optionally roll back)
a deployment if during it any of the alarms trigger.

Alarms can also be added after the Deployment Group is created using the {@link #addAlarm} method.

application.description: The reference to the CodeDeploy Lambda Application that this Deployment Group belongs to.

autoRollback.description: The auto-rollback configuration for this Deployment Group.

deploymentConfig.description: The Deployment Configuration this Deployment Group uses.

deploymentGroupName.description: The physical, human-readable name of the CodeDeploy Deployment Group.

ignorePollAlarmsFailure.description: Whether to continue a deployment even if fetching the alarm status from CloudWatch failed.

postHook.description: The Lambda function to run after traffic routing starts.

preHook.description: The Lambda function to run before traffic routing starts.

role.description: The service Role of this Deployment Group.

applicationName.description: The physical, human-readable name of the CodeDeploy Application.

deploymentConfigName.description: The physical, human-readable name of the Deployment Configuration.

alarms.description:

CodeDeploy will stop (and optionally roll back)
a deployment if during it any of the alarms trigger.

Alarms can also be added after the Deployment Group is created using the {@link #addAlarm} method.

application.description: The CodeDeploy EC2/on-premise Application this Deployment Group belongs to.

autoRollback.description: The auto-rollback configuration for this Deployment Group.

autoScalingGroups.description:
The auto-scaling groups belonging to this Deployment Group.

Auto-scaling groups can also be added after the Deployment Group is created
using the {@link #addAutoScalingGroup} method.

[disable-awslint:ref-via-interface] is needed because we update userdata
for ASGs to install the codedeploy agent.

deploymentConfig.description: The EC2/on-premise Deployment Configuration to use for this Deployment Group.

deploymentGroupName.description: The physical, human-readable name of the CodeDeploy Deployment Group.

ec2InstanceTags.description: All EC2 instances matching the given set of tags when a deployment occurs will be added to this Deployment Group.

ignorePollAlarmsFailure.description: Whether to continue a deployment even if fetching the alarm status from CloudWatch failed.

installAgent.description: If you've provided any auto-scaling groups with the {@link #autoScalingGroups} property, you can set this property to add User Data that installs the CodeDeploy agent on the instances.

loadBalancer.description:
The load balancer to place in front of this Deployment Group.

Can be created from either a classic Elastic Load Balancer,
or an Application Load Balancer / Network Load Balancer Target Group.

onPremiseInstanceTags.description: All on-premise instances matching the given set of tags when a deployment occurs will be added to this Deployment Group.

role.description: The service Role of this Deployment Group.

providerName.description: The name of the Jenkins provider that you set in the AWS CodePipeline plugin configuration of your Jenkins project.

serverUrl.description: The base URL of your Jenkins server.

forBuild.description:
Whether to immediately register a Jenkins Provider for the build category.

The Provider will always be registered if you create a {@link JenkinsAction}.

forTest.description:
Whether to immediately register a Jenkins Provider for the test category.

The Provider will always be registered if you create a {@link JenkinsTestAction}.

bufferInterval.description:
The length of time Kinesis Data Firehose will buffer incoming data before calling the processor.

s

bufferSize.description: The amount of incoming data Kinesis Data Firehose will buffer before calling the processor.

retries.description: The number of times Kinesis Data Firehose will retry the processor invocation after a failure due to network timeout or invocation limits.

bufferingInterval.description:
The length of time that Firehose buffers incoming data before delivering it to the S3 bucket.

Minimum: Duration.seconds(60)
Maximum: Duration.seconds(900)

bufferingSize.description:
The size of the buffer that Kinesis Data Firehose uses for incoming data before delivering it to the S3 bucket.

Minimum: Size.mebibytes(1)
Maximum: Size.mebibytes(128)

compression.description:
The type of compression that Kinesis Data Firehose uses to compress the data that it delivers to the Amazon S3 bucket.

The compression formats SNAPPY or ZIP cannot be specified for Amazon Redshift
destinations because they are not supported by the Amazon Redshift COPY operation
that reads from the S3 bucket.

dataOutputPrefix.description:
A prefix that Kinesis Data Firehose evaluates and adds to records before writing them to S3.

This prefix appears immediately following the bucket name.

encryptionKey.description: The AWS KMS key used to encrypt the data that it delivers to your Amazon S3 bucket.

errorOutputPrefix.description:
A prefix that Kinesis Data Firehose evaluates and adds to failed records before writing them to S3.

This prefix appears immediately following the bucket name.

bucket.description: The S3 bucket that will store data and failed records.

logging.description:
If true, log errors when data transformation or data delivery fails.

If `logGroup` is provided, this will be implicitly set to `true`.

logGroup.description: The CloudWatch log group where log streams will be created to hold error logs.

mode.description:
Indicates the mode by which incoming records should be backed up to S3, if any.

If `bucket` is provided, this will be implicitly set to `BackupMode.ALL`.

s3Backup.description: The configuration for backing up source records to S3.

destinations.description:
The destinations that this delivery stream will deliver data to.

Only a singleton array is supported at this time.

deliveryStreamName.description: A name for the delivery stream.

encryption.description: Indicates the type of customer master key (CMK) to use for server-side encryption, if any.

encryptionKey.description: Customer managed key to server-side encrypt data in the stream.

role.description:
The IAM role associated with this delivery stream.

Assumed by Kinesis Data Firehose to read from sources and encrypt data server-side.

sourceStream.description: The Kinesis data stream to use as a source for this delivery stream.

name.description:
Name for the environment variable.

Use `JsonPath` class's static methods to specify name from a JSON path.

value.description:
Value of the environment variable.

Use `JsonPath` class's static methods to specify value from a JSON path.

containerDefinition.description: Name of the container inside the task definition.

command.description: Command to run inside the container.

cpu.description: The number of cpu units reserved for the container.

environment.description:
The environment variables to send to the container.

You can add new environment variables, which are added to the container at launch,
or you can override the existing environment variables from the Docker image or the task definition.

memoryLimit.description: The hard limit (in MiB) of memory to present to the container.

memoryReservation.description: The soft limit (in MiB) of memory to reserve for the container.

cluster.description: The topic to run the task on.

taskDefinition.description:
Task Definition used for running tasks in the service.

Note: this must be TaskDefinition, and not ITaskDefinition,
as it requires properties that are not known for imported task definitions

containerOverrides.description:
Container setting overrides.

Key is the name of the container to override, value is the
values you want to override.

integrationPattern.description:
The service integration pattern indicates different ways to call RunTask in ECS.

The valid value for Lambda is FIRE_AND_FORGET, SYNC and WAIT_FOR_TASK_TOKEN.

parameters.description: Additional parameters to pass to the base task.

heartbeat.description:
Maximum time between heart beats.

If the time between heart beats takes longer than this, a 'Timeout' error is raised.

payload.description:
The JSON that you want to provide to your Lambda function as input.

This parameter is named as payload to keep consistent with RunLambdaTask class.

message.description: The text message to send to the topic.

integrationPattern.description:
The service integration pattern indicates different ways to call Publish to SNS.

The valid value is either FIRE_AND_FORGET or WAIT_FOR_TASK_TOKEN.

messagePerSubscriptionType.description:
If true, send a different message to every subscription type.

If this is set to true, message must be a JSON object with a
"default" key and a key for every subscription type (such as "sqs",
"email", etc.) The values are strings representing the messages
being sent to every subscription type.

subject.description:
Used as the "Subject" line when the message is delivered to email endpoints.

Also included, if present, in the standard JSON messages delivered to other endpoints.

command.description: The command to send to the container that overrides the default command from the Docker image or the job definition.

environment.description:
The environment variables to send to the container.

You can add new environment variables, which are added to the container
at launch, or you can override the existing environment variables from
the Docker image or the job definition.

gpuCount.description:
The number of physical GPUs to reserve for the container.

The number of GPUs reserved for all containers in a job
should not exceed the number of available GPUs on the compute
resource that the job is launched on.

instanceType.description:
The instance type to use for a multi-node parallel job.

This parameter is not valid for single-node container jobs.

memory.description:
The number of MiB of memory reserved for the job.

This value overrides the value set in the job definition.

vcpus.description:
The number of vCPUs to reserve for the container.

This value overrides the value set in the job definition.

jobId.description: The job ID of the AWS Batch job associated with this dependency.

type.description: The type of the job dependency.

jobDefinitionArn.description: The arn of the job definition used by this job.

jobName.description:
The name of the job.

The first character must be alphanumeric, and up to 128 letters (uppercase and lowercase),
numbers, hyphens, and underscores are allowed.

jobQueueArn.description: The arn of the job queue into which the job is submitted.

arraySize.description:
The array size can be between 2 and 10,000.

If you specify array properties for a job, it becomes an array job.
For more information, see Array Jobs in the AWS Batch User Guide.

attempts.description:
The number of times to move a job to the RUNNABLE status.

You may specify between 1 and 10 attempts.
If the value of attempts is greater than one,
the job is retried on failure the same number of attempts as the value.

containerOverrides.description: A list of container overrides in JSON format that specify the name of a container in the specified job definition and the overrides it should receive.

dependsOn.description:
A list of dependencies for the job.

A job can depend upon a maximum of 20 jobs.

integrationPattern.description:
The service integration pattern indicates different ways to call TerminateCluster.

The valid value is either FIRE_AND_FORGET or SYNC.

payload.description: The payload to be passed as parametrs to the batch job.

timeout.description:
The timeout configuration for this SubmitJob operation.

The minimum value for the timeout is 60 seconds.

cluster.description: The topic to run the task on.

taskDefinition.description:
Task Definition used for running tasks in the service.

Note: this must be TaskDefinition, and not ITaskDefinition,
as it requires properties that are not known for imported task definitions

containerOverrides.description:
Container setting overrides.

Key is the name of the container to override, value is the
values you want to override.

integrationPattern.description:
The service integration pattern indicates different ways to call RunTask in ECS.

The valid value for Lambda is FIRE_AND_FORGET, SYNC and WAIT_FOR_TASK_TOKEN.

(Only applicable in case the TaskDefinition is configured for AwsVpc networking)

subnets.description:

platformVersion.description:

Unless you have specific compatibility requirements, you don't need to
specify this.

subnets.description: In what subnets to place the task's ENIs.

arguments.description:
The job arguments specifically for this run.

For this job run, they replace the default arguments set in the job definition itself.

integrationPattern.description:
The service integration pattern indicates different ways to start the Glue job.

The valid value for Glue is either FIRE_AND_FORGET or SYNC.

notifyDelayAfter.description:
After a job run starts, the number of minutes to wait before sending a job run delay notification.

Must be at least 1 minute.

securityConfiguration.description:
The name of the SecurityConfiguration structure to be used with this job run.

This must match the Glue API
[single-line string pattern](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/glue/latest/dg/aws-glue-api-common.html#aws-glue-api-regex-oneLine).

timeout.description:
The job run timeout.

This is the maximum time that a job run can consume resources before it is terminated and enters TIMEOUT status.
Must be at least 1 minute.

clientContext.description: Client context to pass to the function.

integrationPattern.description:
The service integration pattern indicates different ways to invoke Lambda function.

The valid value for Lambda is either FIRE_AND_FORGET or WAIT_FOR_TASK_TOKEN,
it determines whether to pause the workflow until a task token is returned.

If this is set to WAIT_FOR_TASK_TOKEN, the JsonPath.taskToken value must be included
somewhere in the payload and the Lambda must call
`SendTaskSuccess/SendTaskFailure` using that token.

invocationType.description: Invocation type of the Lambda function.

payload.description: The JSON that you want to provide to your Lambda function as input.

qualifier.description: Version or alias of the function to be invoked.

messageBody.description: The text message to send to the queue.

delay.description:
The length of time, in seconds, for which to delay a specific message.

Valid values are 0-900 seconds.

integrationPattern.description:

The valid value is either FIRE_AND_FORGET or WAIT_FOR_TASK_TOKEN.

messageDeduplicationId.description: The token used for deduplication of sent messages.

messageGroupId.description:
The tag that specifies that a message belongs to a specific message group.

Required for FIFO queues. FIFO ordering applies to messages in the same message
group.

parameters.description:
Parameters to invoke the task with.

It is not recommended to use this field. The object that is passed in
the `task` property will take care of returning the right values for the
`Parameters` field in the Step Functions definition.

The various classes that implement `IStepFunctionsTask` will take a
properties which make sense for the task type. For example, for
`InvokeFunction` the field that populates the `parameters` field will be
called `payload`, and for the `PublishToTopic` the `parameters` field
will be populated via a combination of the referenced topic, subject and
message.

If passed anyway, the keys in this map will override the parameters
returned by the task object.

This value overrides the value set in the job definition.

jobDefinitionArn.description: The arn of the job definition used by this job.

jobName.description:
The name of the job.

The first character must be alphanumeric, and up to 128 letters (uppercase and lowercase),
numbers, hyphens, and underscores are allowed.

jobQueueArn.description: The arn of the job queue into which the job is submitted.

arraySize.description:
The array size can be between 2 and 10,000.

If you specify array properties for a job, it becomes an array job.
For more information, see Array Jobs in the AWS Batch User Guide.

attempts.description:
The number of times to move a job to the RUNNABLE status.

You may specify between 1 and 10 attempts.
If the value of attempts is greater than one,
the job is retried on failure the same number of attempts as the value.

containerOverrides.description: A list of container overrides in JSON format that specify the name of a container in the specified job definition and the overrides it should receive.

dependsOn.description:
A list of dependencies for the job.

A job can depend upon a maximum of 20 jobs.

payload.description: The payload to be passed as parameters to the batch job.

key.description:

For the primary key, you must provide all of the attributes.
For example, with a simple primary key, you only need to provide a value for the partition key.
For a composite primary key, you must provide values for both the partition key and the sort key.

table.description: The name of the table containing the requested item.

conditionExpression.description: A condition that must be satisfied in order for a conditional DeleteItem to succeed.

expressionAttributeNames.description: One or more substitution tokens for attribute names in an expression.

expressionAttributeValues.description: One or more values that can be substituted in an expression.

returnConsumedCapacity.description: Determines the level of detail about provisioned throughput consumption that is returned in the response.

returnItemCollectionMetrics.description:
Determines whether item collection metrics are returned.

If set to SIZE, the response includes statistics about item collections, if any,
that were modified during the operation are returned in the response.
If set to NONE (the default), no statistics are returned.

returnValues.description: Use ReturnValues if you want to get the item attributes as they appeared before they were deleted.

name.description: The name of the Step.

actionOnFailure.description: The action to take when the cluster step fails.

args.description: A list of command line arguments passed to the JAR file's main function when executed.

mainClass.description:
The name of the main class in the specified Java file.

If not specified, the JAR file should specify a Main-Class in its manifest file.

properties.description:
A list of Java properties that are set when the step runs.

You can use these properties to pass key value pairs to your main function.

properties.description: A set of properties specified within a configuration classification.

volumeSize.description:
The volume size.

If the volume type is EBS-optimized, the minimum value is 10GiB.
Maximum size is 1TiB

volumeType.description:
The volume type.

Volume types supported are gp2, io1, standard.

iops.description: The number of I/O operations per second (IOPS) that the volume supports.

volumeSpecification.description: EBS volume specifications such as volume type, IOPS, and size (GiB) that will be requested for the EBS volume attached to an EC2 instance in the cluster.

volumesPerInstance.description: Number of EBS volumes with a specific volume configuration that will be associated with every instance in the instance group.

ebsBlockDeviceConfigs.description: An array of Amazon EBS volume specifications attached to a cluster instance.

ebsOptimized.description: Indicates whether an Amazon EBS volume is EBS-optimized.

instanceType.description: An EC2 instance type.

bidPrice.description:
The bid price for each EC2 Spot instance type as defined by InstanceType.

Expressed in USD.

bidPriceAsPercentageOfOnDemandPrice.description: The bid price, as a percentage of On-Demand price.

configurations.description: A configuration classification that applies when provisioning cluster instances, which can include configurations for applications and software that run on the cluster.

ebsConfiguration.description: The configuration of Amazon Elastic Block Storage (EBS) attached to each instance as defined by InstanceType.

weightedCapacity.description: The number of units that a provisioned instance of this type provides toward fulfilling the target capacities defined in the InstanceFleetConfig.

timeoutAction.description: The action to take when TargetSpotCapacity has not been fulfilled when the TimeoutDurationMinutes has expired.

timeoutDurationMinutes.description: The spot provisioning timeout period in minutes.

allocationStrategy.description: Specifies the strategy to use in launching Spot Instance fleets.

blockDurationMinutes.description: The defined duration for Spot instances (also known as Spot blocks) in minutes.

spotSpecification.description: The launch specification for Spot instances in the fleet, which determines the defined duration and provisioning timeout behavior.

instanceFleetType.description:
The node type that the instance fleet hosts.

Valid values are MASTER,CORE,and TASK.

instanceTypeConfigs.description: The instance type configurations that define the EC2 instances in the instance fleet.

launchSpecifications.description: The launch specification for the instance fleet.

name.description: The friendly name of the instance fleet.

targetOnDemandCapacity.description: The target capacity of On-Demand units for the instance fleet, which determines how many On-Demand instances to provision.

targetSpotCapacity.description: The target capacity of Spot units for the instance fleet, which determines how many Spot instances to provision.

maxCapacity.description:
The upper boundary of EC2 instances in an instance group beyond which scaling activities are not allowed to grow.

Scale-out
activities will not add instances beyond this boundary.

minCapacity.description:
The lower boundary of EC2 instances in an instance group below which scaling activities are not allowed to shrink.

Scale-in
activities will not terminate instances below this boundary.

scalingAdjustment.description:
The amount by which to scale in or scale out, based on the specified AdjustmentType.

A positive value adds to the instance group's
EC2 instance count while a negative number removes instances. If AdjustmentType is set to EXACT_CAPACITY, the number should only be
a positive integer.

adjustmentType.description: The way in which EC2 instances are added (if ScalingAdjustment is a positive number) or terminated (if ScalingAdjustment is a negative number) each time the scaling activity is triggered.

coolDown.description: The amount of time, in seconds, after a scaling activity completes before any further trigger-related scaling activities can start.

simpleScalingPolicyConfiguration.description: The type of adjustment the automatic scaling activity makes when triggered, and the periodicity of the adjustment.

market.description:
Not available for instance groups.

Instance groups use the market type specified for the group.

comparisonOperator.description: Determines how the metric specified by MetricName is compared to the value specified by Threshold.

metricName.description: The name of the CloudWatch metric that is watched to determine an alarm condition.

period.description:
The period, in seconds, over which the statistic is applied.

EMR CloudWatch metrics are emitted every five minutes (300 seconds), so if
an EMR CloudWatch metric is specified, specify 300.

evaluationPeriods.description: The number of periods, in five-minute increments, during which the alarm condition must exist before the alarm triggers automatic scaling activity.

namespace.description: The namespace for the CloudWatch metric.

statistic.description: The statistic to apply to the metric associated with the alarm.

threshold.description: The value against which the specified statistic is compared.

unit.description:
The unit of measure associated with the CloudWatch metric being watched.

The value specified for Unit must correspond to the units
specified in the CloudWatch metric.

cloudWatchAlarmDefinition.description:
The definition of a CloudWatch metric alarm.

When the defined alarm conditions are met along with other trigger parameters,
scaling activity begins.

action.description: The conditions that trigger an automatic scaling activity.

name.description:
The name used to identify an automatic scaling rule.

Rule names must be unique within a scaling policy.

trigger.description: The CloudWatch alarm definition that determines when automatic scaling activity is triggered.

description.description: A friendly, more verbose description of the automatic scaling rule.

constraints.description:
The upper and lower EC2 instance limits for an automatic scaling policy.

Automatic scaling activity will not cause an instance
group to grow above or below these limits.

rules.description: The scale-in and scale-out rules that comprise the automatic scaling policy.

instanceCount.description: Target number of instances for the instance group.

instanceRole.description: The role of the instance group in the cluster.

instanceType.description: The EC2 instance type for all instances in the instance group.

autoScalingPolicy.description: An automatic scaling policy for a core instance group or task instance group in an Amazon EMR cluster.

bidPrice.description:
The bid price for each EC2 Spot instance type as defined by InstanceType.

Expressed in USD.

configurations.description: The list of configurations supplied for an EMR cluster instance group.

ebsConfiguration.description: EBS configurations that will be attached to each EC2 instance in the instance group.

market.description: Market type of the EC2 instances used to create a cluster node.

name.description: Friendly name given to the instance group.

availabilityZone.description:
The Amazon EC2 Availability Zone for the cluster.

AvailabilityZone is used for uniform instance groups, while AvailabilityZones
(plural) is used for instance fleets.

availabilityZones.description:
When multiple Availability Zones are specified, Amazon EMR evaluates them and launches instances in the optimal Availability Zone.

AvailabilityZones is used for instance fleets, while AvailabilityZone (singular) is used for uniform instance groups.

additionalMasterSecurityGroups.description: A list of additional Amazon EC2 security group IDs for the master node.

additionalSlaveSecurityGroups.description: A list of additional Amazon EC2 security group IDs for the core and task nodes.

ec2KeyName.description: The name of the EC2 key pair that can be used to ssh to the master node as the user called "hadoop.".

ec2SubnetId.description:
Applies to clusters that use the uniform instance group configuration.

To launch the cluster in Amazon Virtual Private Cloud (Amazon VPC),
set this parameter to the identifier of the Amazon VPC subnet where you want the cluster to launch.

ec2SubnetIds.description:
Applies to clusters that use the instance fleet configuration.

When multiple EC2 subnet IDs are specified, Amazon EMR evaluates them and
launches instances in the optimal subnet.

emrManagedMasterSecurityGroup.description: The identifier of the Amazon EC2 security group for the master node.

emrManagedSlaveSecurityGroup.description: The identifier of the Amazon EC2 security group for the core and task nodes.

hadoopVersion.description: Applies only to Amazon EMR release versions earlier than 4.0. The Hadoop version for the cluster.

instanceCount.description: The number of EC2 instances in the cluster.

instanceFleets.description:
Describes the EC2 instances and instance configurations for clusters that use the instance fleet configuration.

The instance fleet configuration is available only in Amazon EMR versions 4.8.0 and later, excluding 5.0.x versions.

instanceGroups.description: Configuration for the instance groups in a cluster.

masterInstanceType.description: The EC2 instance type of the master node.

placement.description: The Availability Zone in which the cluster runs.

serviceAccessSecurityGroup.description: The identifier of the Amazon EC2 security group for the Amazon EMR service to access clusters in VPC private subnets.

slaveInstanceType.description: The EC2 instance type of the core and task nodes.

terminationProtected.description: Specifies whether to lock the cluster to prevent the Amazon EC2 instances from being terminated by API call, user intervention, or in the event of a job-flow error.

name.description: The name of the application.

additionalInfo.description:
This option is for advanced users only.

This is meta information about third-party applications that third-party vendors use
for testing purposes.

args.description: Arguments for Amazon EMR to pass to the application.

path.description:
Location of the script to run during a bootstrap action.

Can be either a location in Amazon S3 or on a local file system.

args.description: A list of command line arguments to pass to the bootstrap action script.

name.description: The name of the bootstrap action.

scriptBootstrapAction.description: The script run by the bootstrap action.

realm.description:
The name of the Kerberos realm to which all nodes in a cluster belong.

For example, EC2.INTERNAL.

adDomainJoinUser.description:

A user with sufficient privileges to join
resources to the domain.

crossRealmTrustPrincipalPassword.description:
Required only when establishing a cross-realm trust with a KDC in a different realm.

The cross-realm principal password, which
must be identical across realms.

kdcAdminPassword.description: The password used within the cluster for the kadmin service on the cluster-dedicated KDC, which maintains Kerberos principals, password policies, and keytabs for the cluster.

bootstrapActions.description: A list of bootstrap actions to run before Hadoop starts on the cluster nodes.

clusterRole.description:

An IAM role for an EMR cluster. The EC2 instances of the cluster assume this role.

This attribute has been renamed from jobFlowRole to clusterRole to align with other ERM/StepFunction integration parameters.

customAmiId.description: The ID of a custom Amazon EBS-backed Linux AMI.

ebsRootVolumeSize.description: The size of the EBS root device volume of the Linux AMI that is used for each EC2 instance.

kerberosAttributes.description: Attributes for Kerberos configuration when Kerberos authentication is enabled using a security configuration.

logUri.description: The location in Amazon S3 to write the log files of the job flow.

releaseLabel.description: The Amazon EMR release label, which determines the version of open-source application packages installed on the cluster.

scaleDownBehavior.description: Specifies the way that individual Amazon EC2 instances terminate when an automatic scale-in activity occurs or an instance group is resized.

securityConfiguration.description: The name of a security configuration to apply to the cluster.

serviceRole.description: The IAM role that will be assumed by the Amazon EMR service to access AWS resources on your behalf.

stepConcurrencyLevel.description:
Specifies the step concurrency level to allow multiple steps to run in parallel.

Requires EMR release label 5.28.0 or above.
Must be in range [1, 256].

tags.description: A list of tags to associate with a cluster and propagate to Amazon EC2 instances.

visibleToAllUsers.description: A value of true indicates that all IAM users in the AWS account can perform cluster actions if they have the proper IAM policy permissions.

invocationType.description: Invocation type of the Lambda function.

payload.description: The JSON that will be supplied as input to the Lambda function.

payloadResponseOnly.description:
Invoke the Lambda in a way that only returns the payload response without additional metadata.

The `payloadResponseOnly` property cannot be used if `integrationPattern`, `invocationType`,
`clientContext`, or `qualifier` are specified.
It always uses the REQUEST_RESPONSE behavior.

qualifier.description:
Version or alias to invoke a published version of the function.

You only need to supply this if you want the version of the Lambda Function to depend
on data in the state machine state. If not, you can pass the appropriate Alias or Version object
directly as the `lambdaFunction` argument.

retryOnServiceExceptions.description:
Whether to retry on Lambda service exceptions.

This handles `Lambda.ServiceException`, `Lambda.AWSLambdaException` and
`Lambda.SdkClientException` with an interval of 2 seconds, a back-off rate
of 2 and 6 maximum attempts.

productionVariants.description:
An list of ProductionVariant objects, one for each model that you want to host at this endpoint.

Identifies a model that you want to host and the resources to deploy for hosting it.
If you are deploying multiple models, tell Amazon SageMaker how to distribute traffic among the models by specifying variant weights.

kmsKey.description: AWS Key Management Service key that Amazon SageMaker uses to encrypt data on the storage volume attached to the ML compute instance that hosts the endpoint.

tags.description: Tags to be applied to the endpoint configuration.

containerHostName.description:
This parameter is ignored for models that contain only a PrimaryContainer.

When a ContainerDefinition is part of an inference pipeline,
the value of the parameter uniquely identifies the container for the purposes of logging and metrics.

environmentVariables.description: The environment variables to set in the Docker container.

image.description: The Amazon EC2 Container Registry (Amazon ECR) path where inference code is stored.

mode.description: Defines how many models the container hosts.

modelPackageName.description: The name or Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the model package to use to create the model.

modelS3Location.description:
The S3 path where the model artifacts, which result from model training, are stored.

This path must point to a single gzip compressed tar archive (.tar.gz suffix).
The S3 path is required for Amazon SageMaker built-in algorithms, but not if you use your own algorithms.

modelName.description: The name of the new model.

primaryContainer.description: The definition of the primary docker image containing inference code, associated artifacts, and custom environment map that the inference code uses when the model is deployed for predictions.

containers.description: Specifies the containers in the inference pipeline.

enableNetworkIsolation.description:
Isolates the model container.

No inbound or outbound network calls can be made to or from the model container.

role.description: An execution role that you can pass in a CreateModel API request.

subnetSelection.description: The subnets of the VPC to which the hosted model is connected (Note this parameter is only used when VPC is provided).

tags.description: Tags to be applied to the model.

vpc.description: The VPC that is accessible by the hosted model.

name.description: Name of the metric.

regex.description: Regular expression that searches the output of a training job and gets the value of the metric.

algorithmName.description:
Name of the algorithm resource to use for the training job.

This must be an algorithm resource that you created or subscribe to on AWS Marketplace.
If you specify a value for this parameter, you can't specify a value for TrainingImage.

metricDefinitions.description:
List of metric definition objects.

Each object specifies the metric name and regular expressions used to parse algorithm logs.

trainingImage.description: Registry path of the Docker image that contains the training algorithm.

trainingInputMode.description: Input mode that the algorithm supports.

attributeNames.description: List of one or more attribute names to use that are found in a specified augmented manifest file.

s3DataSource.description: S3 location of the data source that is associated with a channel.

compressionType.description: Compression type if training data is compressed.

contentType.description: The MIME type of the data.

inputMode.description: Input mode to use for the data channel in a training job.

recordWrapperType.description:
Specify RecordIO as the value when input data is in raw format but the training algorithm requires the RecordIO format.

In this case, Amazon SageMaker wraps each individual S3 object in a RecordIO record.
If the input data is already in RecordIO format, you don't need to set this attribute.

shuffleConfig.description: Shuffle config option for input data in a channel.

s3OutputLocation.description: Identifies the S3 path where you want Amazon SageMaker to store the model artifacts.

encryptionKey.description: Optional KMS encryption key that Amazon SageMaker uses to encrypt the model artifacts at rest using Amazon S3 server-side encryption.

instanceCount.description: The number of ML compute instances to use.

instanceType.description:
ML compute instance type.

To provide an instance type from the task input, supply an instance type in the following way
where the value in the task input is an EC2 instance type prepended with "ml.":

```ts
new ec2.InstanceType(sfn.JsonPath.stringAt('$.path.to.instanceType'));
```

volumeSize.description: Size of the ML storage volume that you want to provision.

volumeEncryptionKey.description: KMS key that Amazon SageMaker uses to encrypt data on the storage volume attached to the ML compute instance(s) that run the training job.

maxRuntime.description: The maximum length of time, in seconds, that the training or compilation job can run.

message.description:
The message you want to send.

With the exception of SMS, messages must be UTF-8 encoded strings and
at most 256 KB in size.
For SMS, each message can contain up to 140 characters.

topic.description: The SNS topic that the task will publish to.

messageAttributes.description:
Add message attributes when publishing.

These attributes carry additional metadata about the message and may be used
for subscription filters.

messagePerSubscriptionType.description:
Send different messages for each transport protocol.

For example, you might want to send a shorter message to SMS subscribers
and a more verbose message to email and SQS subscribers.

Your message must be a JSON object with a top-level JSON key of
"default" with a value that is a string
You can define other top-level keys that define the message you want to
send to a specific transport protocol (i.e. "sqs", "email", "http", etc)

subject.description:
Used as the "Subject" line when the message is delivered to email endpoints.

This field will also be included, if present, in the standard JSON messages
delivered to other endpoints.

delay.description:
The length of time, for which to delay a message.

Messages that you send to the queue remain invisible to consumers for the duration
of the delay period. The maximum allowed delay is 15 minutes.

messageDeduplicationId.description:
The token used for deduplication of sent messages.

Any messages sent with the same deduplication ID are accepted successfully,
but aren't delivered during the 5-minute deduplication interval.

messageGroupId.description:
The tag that specifies that a message belongs to a specific message group.

Messages that belong to the same message group are processed in a FIFO manner.
Messages in different message groups might be processed out of order.

Pass the execution ID from the context object to the execution input.

This allows the Step Functions UI to link child executions from parent executions, making it easier to trace execution flow across state machines.

If you set this property to `true`, the `input` property must be an object (provided by `sfn.TaskInput.fromObject`) or omitted entirely.

If this
repository should be owned by a GitHub organization, provide its name

This description is displayed in GitHub after the repository
is created.

enableIssues.description:

You can use GitHub issues to track information
and bugs for your repository.

visibility.description:

If so, you choose who can see and commit to
this repository.

If you specify a name, AWS CloudFormation
converts it to lowercase.
